etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin reducere, from re- ‘back, again’ + ducere ‘bring, lead’. The original sense was ‘bring back’ (hence ‘restore’, now surviving in reduce (sense 5)); this led to ‘bring to a different state’, then ‘bring to a simpler or lower state’ (hence reduce (sense 3)); and finally ‘diminish in size or amount’ (reduce (sense 1), dating from the late 18th century)

definitions: make smaller or less in amount, degree, or size

examples.text: the need for businesses to reduce costs
the workforce has been reduced to some 6,100
a reduced risk of coronary disease

shortDefinitions: make smaller or less in amount or size

definitions: become smaller or less in size, amount, or degree

examples.text: the number of priority homeless cases has reduced slightly

shortDefinitions: become smaller or less in size or degree

definitions: boil (a sauce or other liquid) in cooking so that it becomes thicker and more concentrated

examples.text: increase the heat and reduce the liquid

shortDefinitions: boil sauce or other liquid in cooking so that it becomes thicker and more concentrated

definitions: (of a person) lose weight, typically by dieting

examples.text: by May she had reduced to 125 pounds

definitions: make (a negative or print) less dense.
shortDefinitions: make negative or print less dense

definitions: articulate (a speech sound) in a way requiring less muscular effort. In vowels, this gives rise to a more central articulatory position.
shortDefinitions: articulate speech sound in way requiring less muscular effort

definitions: bring someone or something to (a lower or weaker state, condition, or role)

examples.text: she has been reduced to near poverty
the church was reduced to rubble

definitions: (of a person) be forced by difficult circumstances into doing something desperate

examples.text: ordinary soldiers are reduced to begging

shortDefinitions: be forced by difficult circumstances into doing something desperate

definitions: make someone helpless with (an expression of emotion, especially with hurt, shock, or amusement)

examples.text: Olga was reduced to stunned silence
he succeeds in reducing his grandees to due obedience

definitions: change a substance to (a different or more basic form)

examples.text: it is difficult to understand how lava could have been reduced to dust

definitions: present a problem or subject in (a simplified form)

examples.text: he reduces unimaginable statistics to manageable proportions

definitions: convert a fraction to (the form with the lowest terms).
cause to combine chemically with hydrogen

examples.text: hydrogen for reducing the carbon dioxide

shortDefinitions: cause to combine chemically with hydrogen

definitions: undergo or cause to undergo a reaction in which electrons are gained by one atom from another

examples.text: this compound reduces to potassium chloride
the arsenic is reduced to the trivalent condition

shortDefinitions: undergo or cause to undergo reaction in which electrons are gained from another substance or molecule

definitions: restore (a dislocated part) to its proper position by manipulation or surgery
shortDefinitions: restore dislocated part of body to its proper position by manipulation or surgery

definitions: besiege and capture (a town or fortress).
